titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Asset Based Community Development, Community and Resource Development, Office Files of Frances Korten
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Asset Based Community Development, Community and Resource Development, Office Files of Frances Korten FA250

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-01-16 00:00:15 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Asset Based Community Development, Community and Resource Development, Office Files of Frances Korten

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at https://rockarch.org/collections/access-and-request-materials/#citations

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Standard processing by Katie Martin, December 2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection primarily consists of report drafts with memos and published articles related to the Ford Foundation's efforts to establish community forestry practices in Asia.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frances F. Korten worked as a Ford Foundation program officer for 20 years, from 1977-1996, in Southeast Asia and New York. In the 1970s and '80s, Korten was a program officer in the Jakarta, Indonesia and Manila, Philippines field offices. In the 1990s, she worked in New York as a program officer in the Rural Poverty and Resources and Community and Resource Development units.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into one series: Asia - Community Forestry Review - Material sent to Frances Korten by Peter Geithner

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Between 1976 and 1993, the Ford Foundation invested more than $30 million in support of community forestry programs under the Rural Poverty and Resources Program. Two major goals of the program were to 1.) reduce poverty among people living in rural areas and 2.) improve the management of natural resources. This work required building relationships with nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) as well as government forest departments with jurisdiction over public lands. The program aimed to give people who rely on forests for their livelihood to have a voice in how forests are managed. In the 1980s and 1990s, the Ford Foundation established community forestry programs in the Philippines, India, Thailand, Indonesia, China, and Bangladesh.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2019 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2019:107.
